Holodets (Meat Jelly)

Jump to Recipe

If you're looking to impress your friends and family with a unique and delicious dish, look no further than Holodets, the traditional meat jelly that is a staple in Eastern European cuisine. This savory delicacy, made from tender pork shoulder and beef shank, is not only a feast for the eyes but also a delightful treat for the taste buds. With its rich, flavorful broth infused with aromatic vegetables like carrots, onions, and celery, Holodets is the perfect appetizer for any gathering. Whether served at holiday celebrations or family dinners, this dish showcases the art of cooking with simple ingredients to create something truly special. In this recipe, we will guide you through the process of crafting this classic dish, ensuring that each step is easy to follow. Get ready to dive into the world of Holodets and experience the joy of making your own meat jelly!

Ingredients

pork shoulder

Pork shoulder is a flavorful cut that becomes tender when slow-cooked. Ensure it's well-trimmed to reduce excess fat. If you need a substitute, use pork butt or even beef chuck for a similar texture and flavor profile.

beef shank

Beef shank is ideal for its rich flavor and gelatin content, which contributes to the jellied texture. If unavailable, you can substitute with oxtail or beef brisket, though they may alter the flavor slightly.

carrots

Chopped carrots add sweetness and color. For a different flavor, consider parsnips or sweet potatoes. If you're looking to enhance their sweetness, roast them before adding to the pot.

onion

Quartered onion adds depth to the broth. Use yellow onions for sweetness, or shallots for a milder flavor. If you're out of onions, leeks or green onions can be used as alternatives.

celery stalks

Chopped celery adds a subtle earthiness to the dish. If you don't have celery, you can use fennel or even a small amount of celery salt to impart a similar flavor.

garlic cloves

Smashed garlic infuses the broth with aromatic flavor. If you prefer a milder taste, use roasted garlic. For a substitute, garlic powder can be used, though it won't provide the same depth.

bay leaves

Bay leaves add a fragrant herbal note to the broth. If youâ€™re out, thyme or oregano can work as substitutes, but use less as they are more potent.

peppercorns

Whole peppercorns lend a warm spiciness. If you don't have them, ground black pepper can be used in a pinch, but add it towards the end of cooking to avoid bitterness.

salt

Salt is essential for flavor enhancement. Adjust it to taste, but remember that the broth will concentrate as it simmers, so start with less and add more as needed.

gelatin

Gelatin is crucial for the jellied consistency of Holodets. Make sure to follow the package instructions for dissolving. For a vegetarian option, use agar-agar, but note that it may set differently.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Meat and Broth

    In a large pot, combine the pork shoulder and beef shank with enough water to cover the meat, usually about 10-12 cups. This will create a rich broth for your Holodets.

  • Step 2: Add Vegetables and Seasonings

    Add the chopped carrots, quartered onion, chopped celery, smashed garlic, bay leaves, peppercorns, and salt to the pot. The vegetables not only enhance the flavor but also contribute to the gelatinous texture.

  • Step 3: Bring to a Boil and Simmer

    Bring the mixture to a boil over high heat. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low and let it simmer gently for about 3-4 hours. Stir occasionally and skim off any foam that forms on the surface. The meat should become tender and fall off the bone.

  • Step 4: Strain the Broth

    Once the meat is tender, carefully remove it from the pot. Strain the broth through a fine sieve or cheesecloth into a large bowl to discard the solids. This will leave you with a clear, flavorful broth.

  • Step 5: Cool and Skim the Broth

    Allow the strained broth to cool slightly. As it cools, fat will rise to the surface. Use a spoon to skim off any excess fat for a cleaner taste in your Holodets.

  • Step 6: Shred the Meat

    Shred the cooked meat into bite-sized pieces, discarding any bones or tough bits. This adds texture to the dish.

  • Step 7: Dissolve the Gelatin

    In a separate bowl, dissolve the gelatin in a bit of warm broth according to package instructions. This step is crucial for achieving the right consistency.

  • Step 8: Combine Meat, Broth, and Gelatin

    Mix the shredded meat with the broth and gelatin mixture, stirring well to ensure everything is evenly combined. This is where the magic happens as the gelatin will help set the dish.

  • Step 9: Mold the Mixture

    Pour the combined mixture into a mold or individual serving dishes. Using a mold can enhance the presentation of your Holodets.

  • Step 10: Refrigerate to Set

    Refrigerate the mixture for at least 4 hours, or until it is fully set. For best results, leave it overnight. The longer it sets, the firmer the texture.

  • Step 11: Serve and Enjoy

    Once set, carefully unmold your Holodets onto a serving platter or serve directly from individual dishes. Garnish with fresh herbs or serve with mustard for an extra kick.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I prepare the vegetables for Holodets?

To prepare the vegetables, wash and peel the carrots. Then, chop them into small pieces. For the celery, simply wash and chop the stalks. The onion should be quartered as is, and the garlic cloves just need to be smashed with the flat side of a knife. This will release their flavor.

What if I can't find beef shank?

If beef shank isn't available, you can substitute it with any other bony cut of beef, such as oxtails or beef short ribs, which will also add flavor and gelatin to your dish.

How do I know when the meat is tender?

The meat is tender when it easily pulls apart with a fork. After simmering for 3-4 hours, check by trying to shred a piece of meat; if it falls apart easily, it's ready.

What should I do with the broth after cooking?

After removing the meat, strain the broth through a fine sieve to remove any solids like vegetables and bones. This will give you a clear, flavorful broth for your Holodets.

How do I skim off fat from the broth?

Let the broth cool for a few minutes, then use a spoon to gently skim the fat off the surface. For even easier fat removal, you can refrigerate the broth, allowing the fat to solidify on top for easy removal.

How do I dissolve the gelatin properly?

To dissolve the gelatin, take a small amount of warm broth (not boiling) and sprinkle the gelatin over it. Let it sit for a minute to bloom, then stir until completely dissolved before mixing it with the rest of the broth.

Can I make Holodets in advance?

Absolutely! Holodets can be made a day or two in advance. Just make sure to store it in the refrigerator, and it will set beautifully.

What are some good garnishes for serving Holodets?

Fresh herbs like dill or parsley work great as garnishes. You can also serve it with mustard or horseradish on the side for an extra kick!

How do I store leftover Holodets?

Store any leftover Holodets in an airtight container in the refrigerator. It should keep well for up to 3-4 days.

Is there a vegetarian version of Holodets?

Yes! You can create a vegetarian version using vegetable broth, agar-agar (as a gelatin substitute), and a variety of vegetables like mushrooms, carrots, and celery to mimic the texture.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

Holodets is primarily a meat-based dish; however, for those seeking a vegetarian or vegan alternative, consider using vegetable stock and agar-agar instead of gelatin to create a plant-based version. For gluten-free diets, ensure the bread accompaniments are gluten-free. Additionally, if salt intake is a concern, adjust the seasoning to fit low-sodium dietary needs.

Pairings

For a delightful pairing with Holodets, consider serving it alongside freshly baked rye bread or traditional Russian black bread, which complements the savory flavors of the meat jelly. A side of pickles, such as dill pickles or marinated mushrooms, adds a tangy contrast that enhances the overall experience. For beverages, a light lager or a crisp white wine like Sauvignon Blanc will balance the richness of the dish. For a non-alcoholic option, serve with a chilled kvass or a herbal tea.

Serving Suggestions

Serve Holodets chilled, directly from the refrigerator, to maintain its refreshing texture. For presentation, unmold the jelly onto a decorative serving platter and garnish with finely chopped fresh dill or parsley for a pop of color. You can also create small individual servings in ramekins for more formal gatherings. Accompany with a small dish of spicy mustard or horseradish on the side, allowing guests to add their desired heat and flavor. This dish is perfect as an appetizer or part of a charcuterie board at gatherings.

Description

A traditional Eastern European dish, Holodets is a savory meat jelly packed with flavor and served coldâ€”a unique and refreshing dish.

Ingredients

  • pork shoulder: 1.5 pounds
  • beef shank: 1 pound
  • carrots: 2, chopped
  • onion: 1, quartered
  • celery stalks: 2, chopped
  • garlic cloves: 4, smashed
  • bay leaves: 2
  • peppercorns: 1 teaspoon
  • salt: to taste
  • gelatin: 2 packets (or as per package instructions)
